author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: A.I. Photoshopping Is About to Get Very Easy. Maybe Too Easy.
description: The photo-editing program can now generate images of almost anything. Its maker has a plan it hopes will make this less risky than it sounds.
content: Photoshop is the granddaddy of image-editing apps, the O.G. of our airbrushed, Facetuned media ecosystem and a product so enmeshed in the culture that it’s a verb, an adjective and a frequent lament of rappers. Photoshop is also widely used. More than 30 years since the first version was released, professional photographers, graphic designers and other visual artists the world over reach for the app to edit much of the imagery you see online, in print and on billboards, bus stops, posters, product packaging and anything else the light touches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Taj and Marco Garro
title: As Protesters Die, a Nation’s Security Forces Face Little Scrutiny
description: In Peru, investigations into the killing of protesters by security forces are often closed without any charges, undermining people’s faith in their government.
content: In the adobe house she built with her husband in a small village in Peru, Antonia Huillca pulled out a stack of documents that once represented a glimmer of hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg, Devika Girish, Elisabeth Vincentelli, Robert Daniels and Dina Gachman
title: The Most Anticipated Genre Movies of the Summer
description: Our genre experts pick the films they are most excited about seeing.
content: From web-slinging diversions to archaeological excursions, this summer movie season is stacked with releases across a variety of genres. Our writers who seek out the most interesting picks in horror, international, science fiction, action and children’s movies each month scoured the summer calendar to come up with the films that have their attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Orr
title: ‘Ted Lasso,’ Season 3, Episode 11 Recap: Home
description: Jamie, Nate and Ted find their paths forward.
content: Just as last season’s eighth episode, “Man City,” was an exploration of the wounds inflicted by poor fathering, this week’s focuses on the healing power of maternal love. It was in that earlier episode that we first learned that Ted’s dad had killed himself; this time, he and his mom find at least a modicum of long-belated closure. And Ted has what appears to be the long-simmering revelation that … But I get ahead of myself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Gerard
title: Metalheads Take on the World in John Wray’s New Novel
description: “Gone to the Wolves” follows three young Floridians shredding their way through the heavy metal scenes of the 1980s and ’90s.
content: It’s a miracle anyone survives adolescence. Those who do, do so despite their best efforts to self-destruct. This is one way to read John Wray’s new novel, “Gone to the Wolves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Gabriella Smith’s Music Marvels at Nature With Grooving Joy
description: Smith, a rising young composer, has adapted her work “Lost Coast” into a cello concerto premiering this week at the Los Angeles Philharmonic.
content: In 2014, the composer Gabriella Smith took a hike through the Lost Coast in Northern California. Populated by bears, mountain lions and Roosevelt elk, it’s an area so rugged that the scenic Highway 1, which runs along the water, has to detour far inland. She kept a tide log on hand for portions of the trail that follow the shore. “You have to be careful,” she said, “not to be swept away.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: No Time Like the Present, Senator Feinstein
description: The country shouldn’t discriminate against older workers, and older workers shouldn’t insist on staying in jobs they can no longer really carry out.
content: Dianne Feinstein is giving old age a bad name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: Avedon at 100: Photos of Seduction
description: At Gagosian, Marian Anderson, Marilyn Monroe, Dovima and a cast of showstoppers.
content: Seductive and detail-oriented, Richard Avedon could have been a successful director — and in fact, he was. From his beginnings in fashion to his development as a portraitist, his photography consisted of staged performances where he enthralled sitters with his charm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Kolker
title: A Cop, a Doctor, a Criminal and the 1960 Murder That Connected Them
description: In “Genealogy of a Murder,” Lisa Belkin maps the meandering roads that wound through families and decades before intersecting in tragedy.
content: Alvin Tarlov first met Joseph DeSalvo in the prison hospital at the Stateville Penitentiary in Illinois. Their reasons for being there couldn’t have been more different: Tarlov, a doctor just a few years out of medical school, was running a malaria drug trial, using the prisoners as subjects; DeSalvo, a convicted criminal with a mile-long rap sheet, was an inmate working as a medical technologist, handling insects, slides and the like for doctors like Tarlov. DeSalvo had impressed everyone around him with his work ethic and intelligence — he might have been the only one in the lab to recite poetry while he worked — and when the inmate asked Tarlov to write a recommendation letter to help line up a job contingent on his parole, the doctor was more than willing to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: For a Wine Critic, Experience and Experimentation Age Well
description: Eric Asimov, the wine critic for The New York Times, explains how a diversity of wines has transformed the industry he covers.
content: Boxed wine. Nonalcoholic wine. Even weed wine. Wine isn’t exactly what it used to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Advice Do You Have for the Graduates of 2023?
description: A New York Times Opinion writer urges the class of ’23 to remember that “the world is beautiful. And most people are good.” Do these words resonate with you?
content: Graduation season is a time to celebrate your achievements, share your memories and embrace the exciting possibilities that lie ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Redburn
title: All Americans Have the Right to Dress Exactly How They Want
description: The key to a successful legal campaign is realizing that gender freedom benefits everyone.
content: Transgender Americans are under attack. Across the country, Republicans have introduced an avalanche of legislation to restrict access to gender-affirming health care, censor how gender is discussed in schools, prevent trans people from using public bathrooms and even ban drag shows and cross-dressing onstage. In March, Tennessee criminalized drag performances where children are present. In April, Montana Republicans barred Representative Zooey Zephyr from the floor of the state House in part for her vocal opposition to a similar bill, which is now headed to the governor’s desk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Tina Turner, Magnetic Singer of Explosive Power, Is Dead at 83
description: Hailed in the 1960s for her dynamic performances with her first husband, Ike, she became a sensation as a recording artist, often echoing her personal struggles in her songs.
content: Tina Turner, the earthshaking singer whose rasping vocals, sexual magnetism and explosive energy made her an unforgettable live performer and one of the most successful recording artists of all time, died on Wednesday at her home in Küsnacht, Switzerland, near Zurich. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Decades Old? No Problem: Publisher Makes a Bet on Aging Books
description: A company is republishing books that have fallen out of print and finding new ways to market works that are years, even decades, old.
content: The life of a good book can span hundreds of years, but most of the time, a book gets a flash of attention when it is first published — if its author is lucky. Then, it fades away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and David Montgomery
title: Texas G.O.P. Leaders Clash Over Accusations of Corruption and Drunkenness
description: Attorney General Ken Paxton accused the Republican House speaker of being intoxicated, as he suggested that lawmakers were preparing to impeach him over corruption allegations.
content: The Texas Capitol was unexpectedly gripped by an escalating intraparty showdown among top Republicans on Wednesday after a House committee took steps toward a possible impeachment of the Republican attorney general, Ken Paxton, over charges of corruption and abuse of office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: After France Bans Short Domestic Flights, It’s Business as Usual
description: A decree formalizing the measure, which was passed in 2021, is riddled with exceptions. Critics call its effect symbolic, at best.
content: When the French government officially enacted a ban on short domestic flights this week, it hailed the measure as proof that France was at the vanguard of ambitious climate change policies. But critics say it’s much ado about almost nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen Warns of Missed Payments if Debt Limit Is Not Lifted
description: The Treasury secretary said the Biden administration would face “very tough choices” if Congress did not act.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Wednesday that it was “almost certain” that the United States would not have enough cash to continue to pay all of its bills on time beyond early June and that she would soon provide Congress with a more precise update about when the nation could default if the debt limit was not raised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Netanyahu Budget Shores Up Coalition, but May Risk His Economic Legacy
description: Israel’s prime minister has long advocated a small state, free markets and benefit cuts. But his new budget is heavy on subsidies for the ultra-Orthodox community, whose political support he needs.
content: For decades, Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister, has been a champion of free-market economic doctrine. As finance minister 20 years ago, he cut welfare payments, curbed government spending, sped up privatization and promoted the country’s feted tech industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Adam Entous, Eric Schmitt and Anton Troianovski
title: Ukrainians Were Likely Behind Kremlin Drone Attack, U.S. Officials Say
description: American spy agencies do not know exactly who carried out the attack this month, but suggest it was part of a series of covert operations orchestrated by Ukraine’s security services.
content: U.S. officials said the drone attack on the Kremlin earlier this month was likely orchestrated by one of Ukraine’s special military or intelligence units, the latest in a series of covert actions against Russian targets that have unnerved the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: 95-Year-Old in Australia Dies Days After Police Officer Used Stun Gun on Her
description: Hours before Clare Nowland died, the police announced charges against the officer who used the stun gun on her in the care facility where she lived.
content: A 95-year-old Australian woman whom a police officer in Australia used a stun gun on last week has died in a hospital, the authorities said on Wednesday, not long after announcing charges against the officer, who used the stun gun to repel her when she approached him while holding a steak knife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson, Olivia Bensimon, Wesley Parnell and Michael D. Regan
title: Teenagers Resent Social Media. They Also Resent Efforts to Take It Away.
description: After the surgeon general warned that social media harms young people, young New Yorkers agreed. Some also said that the government — and their parents — should back off.
content: In Manhattan, one high school freshman said he was trying to cut down on scrolling through TikTok, but questioned whether age restrictions on social media use could ever effectively stop tech-savvy teenagers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: With Climate Panel as a Beacon, Global Group Takes On Misinformation
description: A group of scholars introduced an international panel to study the digital information landscape, inspired by those who had been warning of the effect of global warming.
content: Two years ago, at a virtual gathering organized by the Nobel Foundation, Sheldon Himelfarb outlined the idea that the world’s leading scholars should join forces to study misinformation the way that scientists of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change documented the global effect of carbon emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Shane Goldmacher
title: In Shaky Start, Ron DeSantis Joins 2024 Race, Hoping to Topple Trump
description: The Florida governor, Donald Trump’s strongest challenger since 2016, made an unusual and glitch-marred entrance on Twitter alongside Elon Musk. He now faces a daunting clash with Mr. Trump and his scorched-earth tactics.
content: Ron DeSantis’s long-awaited official entry into the 2024 presidential campaign went haywire at its start on Wednesday during a glitch-filled livestream over Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Police Officer Charged With Punching Man Acting Erratically, Breaking His Nose
description: Prosecutors do not often charge officers for actions in the line of duty, but Alvin L. Bragg, Manhattan’s district attorney, has pressed for police accountability.
content: A New York City police officer patrolling the West Village repeatedly punched an emotionally disturbed man in the face, breaking his nose, according to prosecutors with the Manhattan district attorney’s office who are seeking to hold him criminally accountable.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Legalizing Weed: Was It a Harmful Mistake?
description: Readers react to a column by Ross Douthat that asserted it was. Also: The battle over the debt.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Is ‘The Idol’ as Sleazy as HBO Says?
description: At Cannes, the sex-filled show is drawing plenty of controversy. That just means “we’re about to have the biggest show of the summer,” Sam Levinson says.
content: In March, Rolling Stone published an article detailing the trouble-plagued production of “The Idol,” a new HBO drama from the “Euphoria” creator Sam Levinson. According to the magazine, nearly 80 percent of the show, about a pop singer (Lily-Rose Depp) who falls under the spell of a Svengali figure (the Weeknd), had been filmed with the director Amy Seimetz before Levinson stepped in to rewrite and reshoot the entire thing. As a result, said one crew member, it had transformed from a music-industry satire into a “rape fantasy” in which Depp’s character must endure a series of demeaning sex acts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Igielnik and Andrew Fischer
title: Polls Have Shown DeSantis Trailing Trump
description: The Florida governor fares much better in the polls than the rest of his G.O.P. primary competitors, who remain in the low single digits.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has struggled in recent polling, receiving an average across polls of around 20 percent among Republicans, falling far short of former President Donald J. Trump’s roughly 50 percent. The gap between the two men has grown steadily over the past few months, as Mr. Trump’s share has increased and Mr. DeSantis has lost ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Navy Destroyer Sunk in World War II Is Discovered Off Okinawa
description: The U.S.S. Mannert L. Abele was broken in half by two kamikaze attacks and sank in 4,500 feet of water, killing 84 sailors.
content: A U.S. Navy destroyer sunk in 1945 by a kamikaze aircraft during the Battle of Okinawa in World War II has been discovered by a group of civilian underwater explorers deep in the Pacific Ocean, the group’s leader said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: Elon Musk’s Event With Ron DeSantis Exposes Twitter’s Weaknesses
description: What was supposed to be a crowning moment for Mr. Musk’s Twitter turned into a series of technical glitches.
content: Hosting Florida’s governor, Ron DeSantis, in a Twitter audio event on Wednesday to announce his presidential run was supposed to be a triumphant moment for Elon Musk, the owner of Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Catie Edmondson
title: McCarthy Renews Call for Spending Cuts as Debt Talks Grind On
description: With a potential default just over a week away, a resolution remained elusive and Republican leaders told lawmakers they could return home for the holiday break.
content: With a potential federal default just over a week away, a resolution to the debt limit crisis remained out of reach on Wednesday as White House and top Republican negotiators reported no breakthrough in another marathon day of discussions and members of Congress prepared to leave the capital for the holiday weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anabel Sosa
title: Weird Winter Put Bay Area Beekeepers to the Test
description: Backyard beekeeping has risen in popularity in the Bay Area, but a brisk and rainy winter proved challenging for the novices.
content: You’ve probably heard of backyard chickens in California cities. But backyard beekeeping?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: On the Front Line of an Education Revolution
description: MAKENI, Sierra Leone — Any exasperated parent might be forgiven for wanting a daughter like Alimatu Sesay, a highly motivated 16-year-old who can’t afford schoolbooks but borrows them from wealthier classmates and studies the texts outside every night with a flashlight because her tiny home is crowded and has no electricity.
content: MAKENI, Sierra Leone — Any exasperated parent might be forgiven for wanting a daughter like Alimatu Sesay, a highly motivated 16-year-old who can’t afford schoolbooks but borrows them from wealthier classmates and studies the texts outside every night with a flashlight because her tiny home is crowded and has no electricity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Alex Stern, Rikki Novetsky, Mooj Zadie, Lisa Chow, Lexie Diao, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: Ukraine Lost in Bakhmut. But It Has Much Bigger Plans.
description: The stakes are high as Kyiv prepares for an expected counteroffensive against Russian forces.
content: After almost a year of deadly battle, Russia has claimed victory in the eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut. But what happens now is uncertain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Another Housing Setback for New York: Its Housing Chief Is Resigning
description: A day after Mayor Eric Adams said he would oppose an effort to reduce homelessness by increasing the number of housing vouchers, his top housing official said she would step down.
content: Since Eric Adams became mayor, his response to New York City’s housing crisis has been characterized by enormous challenges, along with some stumbles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What Has Trump Cost American Christianity?
description: The death of Tim Keller is a chance to ponder his faith’s Trump-era path.
content: When religious conservatism made its peace with Donald Trump in 2016, the fundamental calculation was that the benefits of political power — or, alternatively, of keeping cultural liberalism out of full political power — outweighed the costs to Christian credibility inherent in accepting a heathen figure as a political champion and leader.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On TikTok, Pop Music Speeds Up
description: A 12-year-old Miguel song has re-entered the Billboard charts, demonstrating how the app reshapes listening habits.
content: TikTok moves fast: the content stream is relentless and easy to scroll through, and music is often sped-up to accompany it. Listening to pop hits there can be disorienting — the music is familiar, but the pace can be unsettling. Seemingly endless remixes from the nightcore and plugg music scene help shape the sonic experience of the app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristie Koerbel
title: ‘Never a Reason to Take Off Your Socks’: A Flight Attendant’s 12 Etiquette Rules
description: Air travel is going to be busy this summer. With some common sense and courtesy, could flying be … pleasant?
content: After 21 years as a flight attendant, I’ve seen it all. The pandemic heightened tensions on board, with the most extreme incidents of bad passenger behavior escalating to violence. More commonly, though, I see discourteous behavior lead to verbal disagreements, or a general unpleasantness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Nicholas Gray, 86, Dies; Paired Hot Dogs With Papaya to Make a Landmark
description: His Gray’s Papaya, a knockoff of another frankfurter haven, helped turn an unlikely culinary combination into a New York phenomenon.
content: Nicholas Gray, the founder of Gray’s Papaya, a storefront hot-dog stand whose culinary eccentricity, competitive prices, clever sloganeering and apparent immutability earned the affection of New Yorkers young and old, rich and poor, died on Friday at a hospital in Manhattan. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: Awkward Silence: Ron DeSantis’s Bold Twitter Gambit That Flopped
description: The Florida governor wanted to show off his tech savvy by announcing his presidential campaign on Twitter. It quickly devolved into the conference call from hell.
content: It was the announcement not heard ’round the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: The Shortcut to Homemade Milk Candy
description: To make the chewy Filipino candies called pastillas de leche, you would typically simmer milk for hours. But there’s a faster way.
content: The candies taste of milk turned to fudge, of cream and butter at once, with the faintest throb of turf, like a memory of some distant pasture. I used to pillage them from the bowl by the cash register at Chinese restaurants: little White Rabbits, pale chewy logs about an inch long, rolled in edible rice paper that vanished on the tongue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Grimes Invited Anyone to Make A.I. Grimes Songs. Here Are Her Reviews.
description: The producer and pop singer, long a proponent of technological experimentation, has “open-sourced” her voice using new A.I. tools. She’s been impressed by the results.
content: Last month, when “Heart on My Sleeve,” a track credited to A.I. versions of Drake and the Weeknd, became an unauthorized hit online, many in the music industry loudly fretted about the legal and creative risks to come. But Grimes, the producer and pop singer who has long been enthralled with visions of the future, saw opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Robert J. Zimmer, Who Promoted Free Speech on Campus, Dies at 75
description: A mathematician, he was for many years the president of the University of Chicago, where he argued that civility was not a reason to silence discussion.
content: Robert J. Zimmer, a mathematician who as president of the University of Chicago championed diversity not only quantitatively, in the recruitment of students and faculty, but also by protecting free expression on campus with a protocol that was later embraced by dozens of colleges across the country, died on Tuesday at his home in Chicago. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Marks Uvalde Anniversary With Renewed Call to ‘Do Something’
description: In a somber address, the president reiterated a push for tighter gun regulations but offered no new ideas for how to overcome entrenched opposition.
content: President Biden, in a somber speech evoking the pain of the death of two of his own children, implored Congress on Wednesday to “please do something” to stop the flow of guns involved in mass shootings like the school massacre that killed 19 children and two teachers a year ago in Uvalde, Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Bill Lee, Bassist and Composer of Son Spike Lee’s Films, Dies at 94
description: He accompanied a wide range of jazz and folk musicians and scored “She’s Gotta Have It,” “School Daze” “Do the Right Thing” and “Mo’ Better Blues.”
content: Bill Lee, a jazz bassist and composer who scored the early films of his son Spike Lee, wrote folk-jazz operas, led an acclaimed ensemble of bassists and was a prolific sideman for Bob Dylan, Aretha Franklin and others, died on Wednesday morning at his home in Brooklyn. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Unprepared Republicans Are Flooding Into the Presidential Race
description: If they can’t outpace Trump, they’ll lie in wait to catch him limping.
content: On Wednesday, the charmless and awkward Ron DeSantis entered the presidential race. In 2024 Republican primary polling, he consistently comes in second to Donald Trump. He has built his legend on an easy re-election as Florida’s governor and an easy route by which he enacted a slate of bullying and regressive “anti-woke” legislation, thanks to Republicans’ supermajorities in Florida’s Legislature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Fetty Wap Is Sentenced to 6 Years in Prison for Running Drugs
description: Prosecutors said the rapper, best known for his hit “Trap Queen,” glamorized drugs — and sold them even as he made millions from his music.
content: Fetty Wap, a New Jersey rapper who shot to fame with his hit “Trap Queen,” an ode to a romance entangled in the drug trade, was sentenced to six years in federal prison on Wednesday for trafficking narcotics across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: ‘Force of Circumstance’: Casablanca in the East Village
description: Liza Béar’s deadpan anti-thriller returns to the Museum of Modern Art for a limited engagement.
content: A young Moroccan woman slips into Washington, D.C., hoping to provide a journalist with intel on the United States’ clandestine involvement in a war for the contested Western Sahara. Once there, she crosses paths with two clownish compatriots looking to purchase a Washington safe house for the king of Morocco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: What Makes a Garden a Work of Art? Piet Oudolf Explains.
description: The noted designer of the High Line has wisdom to share with other gardeners: “I put plants on a stage and let them perform.”
content: There is a transcendent quality to the gardens of the Dutch designer Piet Oudolf, which overtake us with the sense that we have arrived at a place where we would like — and very much need — to spend more time. Drawn into the complex textural mosaic of muted colors, we can exhale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli
title: After Nearly Collapsing, Indian Billionaire’s Stock Is Back on the Rise
description: Investors have again rushed into the conglomerate controlled by Gautam Adani after a panel signaled that the investigation into the company’s finances was getting nowhere.
content: The Adani Group, a conglomerate that builds and operates ports, power lines and food factories across India, began the year nearly on top of the world — having increased in value tenfold over the previous two years. Its founder and chief executive, Gautam Adani, was ranked the second-richest man on Earth last summer, just behind Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: For One Group of Teenagers, Social Media Seems a Clear Net Benefit
description: Despite the surgeon general’s warning about its risks for youth in general, researchers and teenagers say it can be a “lifeline” for L.G.B.T.Q. youth.
content: The surgeon general’s warning Tuesday about social media’s “profound risk of harm” to young people included a significant qualification. For some of them, the warning said, social media can be beneficial to health in important ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: ‘The Little Mermaid’ Review: The Renovations Are Only Skin Deep
description: Disney’s live-action remake, with Halle Bailey starring as Ariel and a diverse cast, is a dutiful corrective with noble intentions and little fun.
content: The new, live-action “The Little Mermaid” is everything nobody should want in a movie: dutiful and defensive, yet desperate for approval. It reeks of obligation and noble intentions. Joy, fun, mystery, risk, flavor, kink — they’re missing. The movie’s saying, “We tried!” Tried not to offend, appall, challenge, imagine. A crab croons, a gull raps, a sea witch swells to Stay Puft proportions: This is not supposed to be a serious event. But it feels made in anticipation of being taken too seriously. Now, you can’t even laugh at it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Unemployment Is Low, But So Is the National Mood
description: A Fed survey gives a detailed portrait of Americans’ financial lives.
content: Every year the Federal Reserve takes a financial snapshot of America. It tells us how people are making ends meet, or not. Whether they’re (still) living with their parents, if they’ve saved money for retirement, whether they wish they had chosen a different major in college and so on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: DeSantis’s Big Event Underscores a Rightward Move for Twitter
description: The Florida governor’s plan to announce his presidential campaign on the social network is the latest sign of the company’s efforts to court conservatives.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is expected to finally announce his presidential campaign on Wednesday night — but not on a stalwart of conservative media, like Fox News. Instead, the Republican star will do so live on Twitter, in a conversation with Elon Musk. (Fox News will get the first television interview with Mr. DeSantis afterward.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Tina Turner: A Life in Photos
description: A performer who leveraged fringe, sequins and sparkles to electrifying effect onstage.
content: It is hard to think of a boundary Tina Turner didn’t break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Hillary Clinton Says Dianne Feinstein Should Not Resign
description: Mrs. Clinton cited Republican obstruction, not Ms. Feinstein’s health: Republicans would refuse to let Democrats fill her seat on the Senate Judiciary Committee, she said, preventing judicial confirmations.
content: Hillary Clinton weighed in this week on a question that has occupied Senate Democrats and much of the party at large for months: whether Senator Dianne Feinstein of California should resign in light of mounting health problems that have made it difficult for her to do her job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Why It’s Far Too Soon to Say DeSantis Is Done
description: Despite his struggles, fortunes can change very quickly in presidential primaries.
content: Is the Ron DeSantis campaign already over?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Rolf Harris, Disgraced British Entertainer, Dies at 93
description: His career as a musician and a painter over six decades ended abruptly when he was convicted of sexually abusing teenage girls.
content: Rolf Harris, the Australian-born entertainer whose decades-long career on British television ended in disgrace after he was convicted of sexually abusing teenage girls, died on May 10 at his home in Berkshire, England. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: The Eyes of Cillian Murphy
description: The “Oppenheimer” star is carrying a major movie for the first time, a responsibility he takes very seriously. Christopher Nolan wrote it with him in mind.
content: The piercing eyes stare out intently from the cover of “American Prometheus,” a biography of J. Robert Oppenheimer, the scientist who spearheaded the development of the atomic bomb. The book, by Kai Bird and Martin Sherwin, was the inspiration for Christopher Nolan’s much-anticipated “Oppenheimer,” opening July 21. And as Nolan was working on the script, only one actor came to mind: Cillian Murphy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman
title: Hiking Has All the Benefits of Walking and More. Here’s How to Get Started.
description: Exploring the great outdoors offers a host of mental and physical benefits. But there a few things you need to know first.
content: Hiking, a form of exercise older than exercise itself, is so hot right now. From 2020 to 2022, the number of Americans hitting the trails ballooned from around 40 million to nearly 60 million — an 18 percent surge, according to the nonprofit Outdoor Foundation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Resident Doctors End Strike at Elmhurst Hospital
description: The doctors walked off the job earlier this week, in the first strike by New York City hospital doctors in more than 30 years. Their union reached a deal with Mount Sinai, which employs them, on Wednesday.
content: Resident doctors ended a three-day strike at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens after reaching a tentative deal on Wednesday that they say brings them closer to earning as much as their counterparts in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
title: Jan. 6 Rioter Who Reclined in Pelosi’s Office Given Sentence of More Than 4 Years
description: Richard “Bigo” Barnett, who was pictured with his foot on a desk in the speaker’s office, had been convicted of eight crimes for his role in the attack on the Capitol by Trump supporters.
content: An Arkansas man who became notorious for putting his foot on a desk in Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office during the attack on the Capitol by supporters of President Donald J. Trump was sentenced on Wednesday to four and a half years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: DeSantis Allies’ $200 Million Plan for Beating Trump
description: As the Florida governor prepares to enter the 2024 race, his allies are building an army of organizers to flood the states with the first nominating contests.
content: A key political group supporting Ron DeSantis’s presidential run is preparing a $100 million voter-outreach push so big it plans to knock on the door of every possible DeSantis voter at least four times in New Hampshire, Nevada and South Carolina — and five times in the kickoff Iowa caucuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thessaly La Force
title: In ‘Taste the Nation’, Padma Lakshmi’s Focus Is on the Food
description: The host of “Taste the Nation” talks about the do-it-yourself nature of shooting her show.
content: In “Taste the Nation,” which debuted its second season this month on Hulu, Padma Lakshmi, the longtime host of the reality-television competition “Top Chef,” visits various immigrant communities throughout the United States, not only eating their food, but interviewing the people who make it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso
title: Pleasantville, N.Y.: A Walkable Village That Checks ‘All the Boxes’
description: The Westchester community attracts an eclectic mix of residents who appreciate the artsy vibe, the charming homes and the proximity of the city.
content: Before discovering Pleasantville, N.Y., several years ago, Erin Williams lived with her husband and elementary-school-age daughter in a succession of Westchester communities. They bought a house in Ossining, N.Y., but found the commute to Manhattan too time-consuming. And getting around town wasn’t any easier. After selling their house and renting in Manhattan for a while, they moved into a rental in Tarrytown, N.Y., while searching for their next stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rich Lowry
title: He’s Not Dead Yet
description: The pre-mortems on Ron DeSantis are premature. He seems to have the correct theory of the case on how to try to topple Donald Trump.
content: It’s never a good sign when political analysts are writing “What Went Wrong?” stories about your presidential campaign before it’s announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Ron DeSantis Launches His Campaign
description: Also, Tina Turner dies at 83. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida — who rose to conservative stardom in recent years with a flurry of punches to America’s political left — made his long-awaited entrance into the 2024 presidential race this afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: How to Listen to DeSantis’s Presidential Announcement on Twitter
description: The Florida governor is set to announce that he will be running for president on Twitter Spaces, a live audio streaming platform on Twitter where people gather and talk online in real time.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is announcing that he will be running for president at 6 p.m. on Wednesday in a conversation with Elon Musk on Twitter Spaces, a live audio streaming platform on Twitter where people gather and talk online in real time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Tina Turner’s 11 Essential Songs
description: Turner, who died Wednesday at 83, went from R&B shouter to rock queen to pop superstar. Here are some of her greatest musical moments.
content: Like all the greatest pop icons, Tina Turner, who died Wednesday at 83, had more than one life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Semafor Raises $19 Million, Replacing Money From Sam Bankman-Fried
description: The media start-up’s new backers include Henry Kravis, a founder of the private-equity giant KKR, and Jerry Yang, a Yahoo founder.
content: Semafor, the digital-media start-up, has raised $19 million from investors including the Yahoo co-founder Jerry Yang, replacing the money it had received from the disgraced cryptocurrency mogul Sam Bankman-Fried.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Who Is David Sacks? A Fitting Bridge Between DeSantis and Musk
description: The Silicon Valley entrepreneur and investor is a podcast host, friend of Elon Musk and donor to Ron DeSantis.
content: The discussion on Twitter Spaces between Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and Elon Musk, the owner of Twitter, will be moderated by David Sacks, a fitting bridge between them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Women’s Basketball
description: Do women players deserve more respect — and pay?
content: The W.N.B.A. began its 27th season on Friday with a spotlight on it thanks to the attention garnered by Brittney Griner, the center for the Phoenix Mercury who spent nearly 10 months detained in Russia last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Morris
title: Madness, Royalty and the Music of Screams
description: Elaine Mitchener will draw on a range of extended vocal techniques to give a sensitive portrait of mental illness in the music theater piece “Eight Songs for a Mad King.”
content: When the British vocalist Elaine Mitchener performs Peter Maxwell Davies’ “Eight Songs for a Mad King” at Wigmore Hall in London on Friday, a lot will be on her mind: the complex psychology of the work’s central character, the piece’s rich performing history and its sensitive perspective on mental health. That’s before she even gets to the notes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: An Unsparing Memoir of Hardship Transmuted Into Possibility
description: Rachel Louise Snyder lost her mother to cancer at 8 and was kicked out of her high school and her home at 16. “Women We Buried, Women We Burned” chronicles her quest to create a fulfilling life on her own terms.
content: Before Rachel Louise Snyder settled on the subject of her previous book, “No Visible Bruises: What We Don’t Know About Domestic Violence Can Kill Us” (2019), she says she believed “all the common assumptions” about domestic violence: that such harm was private, separable from the harm done to strangers; that shelters usually offered an adequate solution for victims; and that if the brutality became unbearable, a victim could just leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: ‘It Wasn’t a Documentary About Bama Rush Whatsoever!’
description: A new documentary chronicles the TikTok-fueled phenomenon of sorority rush at the University of Alabama. Those who lived through it have thoughts.
content: Last year, as rumors of a secret documentary swirled at the University of Alabama in Tuscaloosa, many students taking part in sorority recruitment were on high alert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Is the Surge to the Left Among Young Voters a Trump Blip or the Real Deal?
description: The question is how long it will last.
content: There is a lot about the American electorate that we are only now beginning to see. These developments have profound implications for the future of both the Republican and the Democratic coalitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Wes Anderson’s ‘Asteroid City’: How Wessy Is It?
description: At the film’s Cannes premiere, the director’s customary cast, themes and even camera moves were all on display — well, except one.
content: Wes Anderson’s directorial style is so distinctive and particular — so Wessy — that it’s spawned no end of recent A.I. parodies. But how do those imitations compare with the real thing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: Bison Calf at Yellowstone Is Euthanized After Man’s Intervention
description: Park officials said they were trying to identify a man who moved the calf after it was separated from its mother and herd, causing the herd to reject it.
content: A bison calf at Yellowstone National Park had to be euthanized after a man apparently tried to help it, causing the herd to reject it, park officials said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: The Times Reaches a Contract Deal With Its Newsroom Union
description: The new agreement, if ratified, will give union members immediate salary increases of up to 12.5 percent.
content: The New York Times reached a deal on Tuesday for a new contract with the union representing the majority of its newsroom employees, ending more than two years of contentious negotiations that included a 24-hour strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Fisher
title: The High-Risk Feat of Bringing ‘American Born Chinese’ to TV
description: For years, Gene Luen Yang was convinced a single character in his groundbreaking graphic novel would doom any attempt at an adaptation. What changed?
content: Almost everyone who reads “American Born Chinese,” Gene Luen Yang’s groundbreaking graphic novel, is a little afraid of Chin-Kee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: Does DeSantis Need to Resign to Run for President? Short Answer: No.
description: Florida has a statute that could have compelled Ron DeSantis to resign as governor to run for president, but state lawmakers adjusted the rules.
content: Hours after filing federal paperwork declaring that he was running for president — and shortly before his plan for a Twitter livestream to launch his campaign went haywire — Gov. Ron DeSantis signed a Florida elections bill that cleared a potential hurdle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: A Fight Over Yachts Is a Battle for the Soul of the North Fork
description: Thousands of residents in the hamlet of Mattituck say a plan to build storage for 88 yachts would destroy the environment and the character of the area.
content: Like the tongue of a snake, Long Island’s eastern edge splits into two distinct tines. To the south lies the cluster of affluent villages known as the Hamptons. To the north is a bucolic strip of farmland that prides itself on its blue-collar roots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen to The Headlines, a New Way to Experience The Times
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Why the ‘Rules’ of Politics Don’t Always Stymie Outsiders to the System
description: For decades, many voters grew accustomed to a certain set of norms that seemed to govern political systems like rules. But elite groups have lost the power they once had to enforce those norms, or decided to change their own behavior.
content: Over the years, I’ve noticed a recurring pattern in the emails I receive from readers about my columns on authoritarianism, far-right populism, democratic backsliding and related topics: a very similar type of shock at the news, and a very similar type of concern about what that might mean for the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Funky Bit of Noodling
description: Kavin Pawittranon and Nijah Morris help us connect the dots to celebrate a special occasion.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: A Year After the Uvalde Massacre: Did Anything Change?
description: After a failed police response to the shooting deaths of 19 students and two teachers in Uvalde, Texas, there were calls for accountability and new gun laws.
content: The shooting at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, last May in some ways changed the conversation yet again on gun violence in the United States: 19 fourth-grade students and two teachers died in one of the deadliest school shootings in American history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Florida School Restricts Access to Amanda Gorman’s Inauguration Poem
description: A grade school in Miami-Dade County said “The Hill We Climb,” which Ms. Gorman read at President Biden’s inauguration in 2021, was “better suited” for older students after a parent complained about it.
content: Amanda Gorman, who in 2021 became the youngest inaugural poet in United States history when she spoke at President Biden’s swearing-in, said she was “gutted” this week after a Florida school said the poem she recited that day was inappropriate for its youngest students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Orcas Sank 3 Boats in Southern Europe in the Last Year, Scientists Say
description: A small group of orcas is ramming into sailboats in waters off the Iberian Peninsula. Researchers say they do not know what is driving the unusual behavior toward boats.
content: Hours into a journey to Portugal from Morocco, the crew of a 46-foot sailing cruiser noticed something was wrong with the rudder. Then, someone shouted what they saw slicing through the choppy waves: “Orcas! Orcas!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: A Paralyzed Man Can Walk Naturally Again With Brain and Spine Implants
description: In a new study, researchers describe a device that connects the intentions of a paralyzed patient to his physical movements.
content: Gert-Jan Oskam was living in China in 2011 when he was in a motorcycle accident that left him paralyzed from the hips down. Now, with a combination of devices, scientists have given him control over his lower body again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Father Was Awful. Do I Have to Plan His Funeral?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what an adult child owes an estranged parent.
content: After a childhood spent shuttling between divorced parents, my relationship with my father (with whom I never lived full time) became rote and dreaded as I matured into adulthood. Not only did I recognize he was a deeply unhappy person with addiction issues which occasionally placed me in danger, I was always bothered by his racist, misogynistic and homophobic jokes. These and other behaviors became intolerable to me as I entered my 20s, and I distanced myself until firmly cutting off all contact about five years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Chicken for Lemon Lovers
description: White meat chicken, artichoke hearts and lemon slices are fried and lacquered in a buttery, winy pan sauce.
content: When I was growing up, a heated debate broke out over the chicken whenever my parents took our family out for Italian food. My father, a dark-meat and garlic guy to his core, espoused the charms of chicken scarpariello. But my lemon-loving mother preferred chicken francese — batter-fried chicken breasts with their tangy, winy, citrus-imbued pan sauce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison
title: Default on U.S. Debt Risks ‘Permanently’ Denting Nation’s Credit Rating
description: If the government misses an interest payment, even by a few hours, its creditworthiness will suffer, possibly for a long time.
content: If the U.S. government defaults on its debt even for just a few hours next week, it could have long-lasting consequences for the nation’s future. Three major ratings companies — S&P Global Ratings, Moody’s and Fitch Ratings — play a big role in how damaging those consequences can be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: Summer Movies 2023: Here’s What’s Coming to Theaters and Streaming
description: Barbie springs to life, Indy swings into action and Spidey slings new webs. Here are 107 films for movie lovers of all tastes.
content: Here is a list of noteworthy movies heading to theaters and living rooms this summer — everything from blockbusters to small indies from the festival circuit. Release dates and platforms are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: It’s the 140th Birthday of the Brooklyn Bridge
description: The Brooklyn Bridge still stands alone as an attraction and as a symbol of New York’s ability to strive for great things.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll say happy birthday to the Brooklyn Bridge with someone who says it was, and is, a symbol of progress and optimism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Lowenstein
title: The Way Out of the Debt Crisis Could Lead Back Through the Civil War
description: President Lincoln and Republicans in Congress recognized that preserving America’s credit was the key to financing the Civil War and therefore to the government’s survival.
content: The looming American debt crisis is politically contrived. The Treasury could borrow all it needed if the Republican majority in the House acted responsibly and raised the debt ceiling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Ron DeSantis’s presidential bid.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida intends to announce the start of his 2024 presidential campaign this evening in a live conversation on Twitter with Elon Musk, the platform’s owner, moderated by the Republican donor David Sacks. DeSantis will also appear on Fox News in an interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: M.L.B.’s New Rules Have Baseball in Overdrive
description: Players are stealing more bases, more balls are falling for hits and games are nearly 30 minutes faster than they were last year. Like them or not, the rules are accomplishing their goals.
content: Nearly two months into baseball’s pitch-clock era, you sometimes wonder how the sport ever got so slow. Why did we endure standstill traffic on a ride that could have been much smoother?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Bill to Force Texas Public Schools to Display Ten Commandments Fails
description: A Republican effort to bring religion into classrooms faltered, though lawmakers were poised to allow chaplains to act as school counselors.
content: A push to inject religion into public schools across Texas faltered on Tuesday after the State House failed to pass a contentious bill that would have required the Ten Commandments to be displayed prominently in every classroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: The 2026 Winter Olympics Are Looking Beyond the Horizon
description: Andrea Varnier, chief executive of the Milan-Cortina organizing committee, talks about managing the most sprawling Games in history, and why he thinks it could be a model for future Olympics.
content: The floor-to-ceiling windows in Andrea Varnier’s 44th-floor office offer a sweeping view of Milan and some of the mountains that will host the 2026 Winter Olympics, but Varnier jokes that the panorama is not for him. He is almost never in this office, he admits. He rarely uses the desk. There is just no time to sit still, he says with a shrug.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shaila Dewan
title: In Capitols and Courthouses, No End to National Divide Over Gun Policy
description: After the Supreme Court ruled last year that people could carry guns outside their homes, legal challenges and legislative debates have been playing out across the country.
content: Less than a month after 19 children and two teachers died in the elementary school shooting last year in Uvalde, Texas, the U.S. Senate passed the most significant gun control bill since the long-expired federal ban on assault weapons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalia Richardson
title: Halle Bailey: ‘The Little Mermaid’ Star Connects With Her Inner Ariel
description: Her first major film role has come with big expectations and a racist backlash. But the Grammy-nominated singer isn’t easily deterred.
content: Emotions wash over Halle Bailey in waves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Demons’ Review: Grief Is the Thing With Red Fur
description: A family processes its bereavement in the midst of a demonic haunting in Keelay Gipson’s new play for Bushwick Starr.
content: When Danily, a red-furred, purple-lipped beast, appears onstage, his giant eyelids fluttering and huge maw flapping, he is irresistibly adorable, like something from Jim Henson’s dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The DeSantis Delusion
description: The Florida governor’s bid for the presidency is a deeply puzzling — and possibly doomed — one.
content: If Ron DeSantis is supposed to be more electable than Donald Trump, why did he sign a ban on most abortions in Florida after six weeks of pregnancy? That’s manna for the Christian conservatives who matter in Republican primaries, but it’s a liability with the moderates and independents who matter after that point. It steps hard on DeSantis’s argument that he’s the version of Trump who can actually beat President Biden. It flattens that pitch into a sad little pancake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: 3 Smart Techniques for Better (and Beautiful) Strawberry Desserts
description: Those luscious berries have a downside: All that liquid can weigh down baked goods, but Melissa Clark has solutions.
content: Last winter was a terrible time to be a strawberry in California — and maybe an even worse time to be a strawberry farmer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: She’s Out to Save Rare Wildflowers, but First She Has to Find Them
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, May 24, 2023.
content: “Oh my god! A hybrid!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josie Moyer, Mar-Vic Cagurangan, Mike Ives and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Mawar Gains Strength After Thrashing Guam, Becoming a Super Typhoon
description: Island residents experienced howling winds and periods of intense rainfall, which left most of Guam without power. Officials had yet to assess the damage, but typhoon warnings remained in effect.
content: Guam residents woke up Thursday to survey the damage after a long night of whipping winds and lightning storms from Mawar, a typhoon that downed coconut and mango trees and knocked out power across much of the U.S. Pacific territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Chinese Malware Hits Systems on Guam. Is Taiwan the Real Target?
description: The code, which Microsoft said was installed by a Chinese government hacking group, set off alarms because Guam would be a centerpiece of any U.S. military response to a move against Taiwan.
content: Around the time that the F.B.I. was examining the equipment recovered from the Chinese spy balloon shot down off the South Carolina coast in February, American intelligence agencies and Microsoft detected what they feared was a more worrisome intruder: mysterious computer code appearing in telecommunications systems in Guam and elsewhere in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Britain’s Inflation Slowed in April but Remains Stubbornly High
description: Consumer prices rose 8.7% from a year earlier, the slowest pace since March 2022.
content: Britain’s inflation rate dropped to its lowest level in more than a year in April as the effects of last year’s surge in energy prices started to ease.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 24, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, May 24, 2023.
content: An article on Saturday about Ron DeSantis’s private air travel characterized his career incorrectly. He has worked in public service nearly his entire career, but not his entire career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Potential Debt Ceiling Deal Would Barely Change Federal Spending Path
description: Negotiators have focused on a relatively small corner of the budget, shunning new revenues or cuts to the fastest-growing programs
content: As their debt limit negotiations with President Biden push the nation perilously close to a devastating default, House Republicans have stuck to a clear message: They must force a change in what they call the nation’s “unsustainable” spending path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Strategic Fashioning of Casey DeSantis
description: With an eye to the Kennedys, and the Trumps. Sometimes, a wardrobe is a strategy.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has finally, officially, entered the presidential race. The long-anticipated Trump-DeSantis matchup is about to hit prime time. Which means that so, too, is what Mr. DeSantis himself called in his recent book, “The Courage to Be Free,” the “Ron and Casey traveling road show,” a Camelot-meets-Mar-a-Lago by way of Disney series that is now going national. And while Mr. DeSantis may be the nominal star, it is his wife, in her supporting role, who has been making the most notable entrances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: George Washington University Drops Colonial Moniker
description: The move comes after criticism of the team’s nickname because of its association with violence toward Native Americans and other colonized people.
content: George Washington University announced a new name — Revolutionaries — for its athletic teams on Wednesday, after years of pressure from students who said the previous moniker, “Colonials,” glorified violence toward Native Americans and other colonized people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Texas Man Who Tried to Breach Speaker’s Lobby on Jan. 6 Gets 7 Years
description: Christopher R. Grider had also tried to shut off the electricity at the U.S. Capitol, according to prosecutors.
content: A Texas man who joined other rioters at the U.S. Capitol trying to break into the Speaker’s Lobby, where a woman who was a part of the mob on Jan. 6, 2021, was fatally shot by the police, was sentenced on Tuesday to nearly seven years in prison, the Justice Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: DeSantis’s Presidential Run
description: Also, China cracks down on comedy.
content: Ron DeSantis, the governor of Florida, entered the presidential race yesterday, filing paperwork to declare his candidacy. DeSantis will announce the start of his campaign on Twitter, in a conversation with Elon Musk, which is set to start at 6 p.m. Eastern (8 a.m. in Sydney; 6 a.m. in Hong Kong).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: I Used a Slur for Accuracy When Repeating a Joke. Why Is Everyone Upset?
description: A reader asks whether she has to apologize after recounting a joke that used racist language in front of her son’s friend, who later said he had felt unsafe.
content: My son is a comedian. When his comedian friends come to my town for gigs, I put them up. Recently, I hosted a Black friend of his — I am white — and we talked about a famous Black comic. I paraphrased one of the comic’s jokes that impressed me: A TV censor allowed the comic to use the N-word but objected to his use of a gay slur. When the comic asked why, the censor said: “Because you’re not gay.” The comic replied: “Well, I’m not a N-word, either.” I used the full N-word, as the comic had, for accuracy. Later, the guest told my son that my language had made him feel unsafe and that I am a racist. My son is angry with me. But I am stunned that he and his friend can’t distinguish between quoting an antiracist joke and being racist. Do I have to apologize?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Police Commissioner Recommends Discipline for Top N.Y.P.D. Chief
description: Commissioner Keechant Sewell has decided Jeffrey Maddrey should be punished for freeing a retired officer arrested after chasing three boys while armed with a gun.
content: Commissioner Keechant Sewell has proposed punishment for one of the New York Police Department’s top chiefs after accusations that he interfered with the arrest of a retired officer who chased three boys while armed, according to two people with knowledge of her decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Work Hard Have Fun Make History’ Review: Labor, Meet Greed
description: Clubbed Thumb’s Summerworks festival opener, written by ruth tang, rages against the machines and examines human alienation.
content: Like a dog nosing around in the background, a robot vacuum cleaner is a guaranteed scene stealer. Late in the new play “Work Hard Have Fun Make History,” the unfailingly compelling actor Susannah Perkins shares the stage with one: a whirring black disk busily roaming the industrial carpet, bumbling into walls yet never toppling over edges, at least not the night I saw the show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Tweens Shouldn’t Be on Social Media. Can Smartwatches Help Keep Them Off?
description: The surgeon general said social media can be a “profound risk” for America’s youth.
content: On Tuesday, Surgeon General Vivek Murthy released a public advisory about the hazardous potential of social media on youth mental health. I was pleased to see that it’s a balanced summary of what we know and a clear explanation of the gaps in the evidence and not just a typical anti-social-media screed. The report explains that social media has some benefits, like social connection, particularly for marginalized groups, but the risks may outweigh the rewards, depending on the individual kid and propensities toward maladies like depression, anxiety, neurosis and eating disorders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: This Is What ‘Productive’ Looks Like in Washington as Default Deadline Looms
description: A debt crisis could be only a week away — practically an eternity in a town governed by the threat of catastrophic deadlines.
content: House Speaker Kevin McCarthy said this week that he did not believe Republicans and Democrats were anywhere close to a deal on raising the debt ceiling. President Biden said little in public. As the risk of default drew closer, Republicans got together and auctioned off a tube of used cherry lip balm, which sold for six figures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.7 Million Homes in New York, Florida and Michigan
description: A Carpenter Gothic showplace in Shelter Island Heights, an 1890 home in Key West and a midcentury-modern house in Bloomfield Hills.
content: This house is in Shelter Island Heights, a hamlet in the town of Shelter Island, in Suffolk County. The neighborhood, which is notable for its well-preserved Victorian homes, was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1993. The property is a short walk from Grand Avenue, home to a hardware store, a post office, a coffee shop and an inn in a building dating to the 1870s. It is less than half a mile from the Shelter Island Heights Private Beach Club; access to the club’s beach and its tennis courts comes with ownership of the house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: The Wagner group forecasts disaster if Russia does not move into total war footing.
description: Yevgeny Prigozhin has been ramping up pressure on Russia’s military leadership and extending his criticism to the country’s moneyed elites.
content: As Russia vowed to respond “extremely harshly” to a rare, two-day border incursion by pro-Ukrainian fighters, the leader of Russia’s largest mercenary force warned that it faced further setbacks unless its ruling elite took drastic, and likely unpopular, measures to win the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Biden to Nominate Air Force Chief to Succeed Milley on Thursday
description: If confirmed by the Senate, the Air Force chief of staff would become the senior military adviser to the president.
content: President Biden intends to nominate Gen. Charles Q. Brown, the Air Force chief of staff, on Thursday to become the country’s most senior military officer, formalizing what had been one of the worst kept secrets in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Chief Justice Says Supreme Court Is Working to Address Ethics Questions
description: In remarks at an awards ceremony, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. also addressed heckling at law schools and security for members of the court.
content: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. said on Tuesday night that he and his colleagues on the Supreme Court were continuing to take steps to address questions about the justices’ ethical standards amid a barrage of allegations of misconduct and a push by some lawmakers to tighten the rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: Quite a Tail: A Mouse Has Been Hiding Its Armor All This Time
description: Researchers just discovered that the spiny mouse was concealing bony plates beneath the skin over its tail.
content: At first it looks like a slightly more hairy rodent. But the spiny mouse’s body is full of secrets. Found in rock outcrops throughout Africa and Europe, its back is full of porcupine-like quills made of stiffened fur. It has soft, easily torn skin and a remarkable ability to regenerate, like a species of desert gecko. Now, researchers have revealed another surprise in the journal iScience on Wednesday: Their tails are lined with osteoderms, or bony plates, making them only the second group of living mammals known to be equipped with underskin armor like an armadillo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: What’s Next for Russia After Spilling So Much Blood for Bakhmut?
description: Seizing the city took 10 months and untold lives. Most likely, analysts say, Russia’s exhausted forces will settle into a defensive crouch, preparing for Ukraine’s counteroffensive.
content: The battle for the eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut is essentially over, for now. After 10 months of brutal artillery duels, frantic troop advances and thousands of Russian and Ukrainian casualties, Moscow’s formations are in control of the industrial hub, while Kyiv’s troops are trying to put pressure on the city’s flanks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Florida’s First Lady, and Second in Command
description: Casey DeSantis has advised her husband on media strategy and taken on some of the state’s big issues. The presidential campaign trail is next.
content: During a recent appearance in South Carolina, after Ron DeSantis played up his state’s economic and education policies and bashed a litany of ideological adversaries, his wife settled into an armchair next to him onstage, reflecting on her role as the first lady of Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: gait
description: This word has appeared in 68 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word gait has appeared in 68 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 21 in “A Winter Workout That Can Take You Somewhere Stunning” by Amanda Loudin:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: It’s Millionaire vs. Billionaire in the Battle of the SoHo Pergola
description: The rooftop of a historic building is the focus of a renovation skirmish between Federico Pignatelli, a financier, and Ray Dalio, the hedge-fund mogul.
content: Millions of Americans embarked on home-improvement projects during the pandemic. Many of those projects annoyed their neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: This Is Not an Extraterrestrial Signal. This Is Just a Test.
description: You too could be Jodie Foster as astronomers organize a practice run in communicating with aliens.
content: In the 1997 movie “Contact,” Jodie Foster plays an astronomer, Ellie Arroway, who detects an alien radio signal from outer space. Eventually the fictional Dr. Arroway goes on a trip through hyperspace to commune with an alien presence appearing in the form of her dead father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Lim
title: Kenneth Anger, 96, Dies; Experimental Filmmaker Left a Pop Culture Legacy
description: His movie, “Scorpio Rising,” proved that sound and image could be combined to create something powerful, influencing the rise of music video.
content: Kenneth Anger, a child of Hollywood who became one of the most important experimental filmmakers of his generation and whose influence can still be felt in popular visual culture, from movies to music videos, died on May 11  in Yucca Valley, Calif., a town bordering Joshua Tree National Park. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: What to Know About Limiting Your Child’s Screen Time
description: Concerned parents have many tools, including free software from Apple and Google, to actively oversee how children use their tech.
content: Attention, parents with “screenagers”: The U.S. government has issued a public warning that scrolling through apps like TikTok, Instagram and Snapchat may pose serious risks to your child’s mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Fed Officials Were Split Over June Rate Pause, Minutes Show
description: In the Federal Reserve’s last meeting, “several” participants thought rates may have moved high enough to get inflation under control.
content: Federal Reserve officials were unanimous in their decision to raise interest rates earlier this month, but were conflicted over whether additional increases would be necessary to bring inflation under control, according to minutes from the Fed’s last meeting released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: These Rites of Spring Push Back at Ruthlessness
description: The South African choreographer and dancer Dada Masilo’s “The Sacrifice,” at the Joyce Theater, responds to Pina Bausch.
content: Over the past decade, the South African choreographer Dada Masilo has become internationally known and respected for her bold, socially conscious adaptations of canonical ballets like “Giselle” and “Swan Lake.” With her current touring production, “The Sacrifice” (2021), she responds to source material that is a bit more contemporary but carries just as much historical weight: Pina Bausch’s “The Rite of Spring,” which Bausch choreographed in 1975 to Stravinsky’s groundbreaking 1913 score. (The music originally accompanied Nijinsky’s earth-pounding modernist choreography, a pairing that caused a riot at the ballet’s Paris premiere.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Amassing Power, DeSantis Maximized Might of Governor’s Office
description: Ron DeSantis methodically expanded his powers and pushed legal boundaries to enact his policies. He suggests he would do the same as president.
content: Few knew what to expect from Ron DeSantis when he was first elected Florida governor in 2018 as a little-known congressman. He had barely eked out a victory. He had almost no ties to the State Capitol. His policy agenda seemed unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Cultural Crackdown in China Shuts Comedy and Music Shows
description: Performances across the country were canceled last week after Beijing began investigating a stand-up comedian.
content: The cancellations rippled across the country: A Japanese choral band touring China, stand-up comedy shows in several cities, jazz shows in Beijing. In the span of a few days, the performances were among more than a dozen that were abruptly called off — some just minutes before they were supposed to begin — with virtually no explanation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: A.I. Needs an International Watchdog, ChatGPT Creators Say
description: To manage its risks, “superintelligent” artificial intelligence should be governed by a body similar to the International Atomic Energy Agency, the lab’s leadership said in note on its website.
content: The leaders of OpenAI, the artificial intelligence research lab that developed the chatbot ChatGPT, have called for regulation of “superintelligent” A.I. technology, saying it “will be more powerful than other technologies humanity has had to contend with in the past.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Lauren Jackson
title: A Year in Uvalde
description: How grief has warped the lives of the Uvalde shooting victims’ families and friends.
content: The United States experiences so many mass shootings that journalists do not usually linger long after the attacks. Reporters and photographers move on to other stories, while the families and friends of the victims continue to grieve.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Fluid Friendship to Fatherhood in Verse
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: UNDER THE BLANKET SKY, by Tim Fischer. (Doubleday, $18.99, ages 3 to 7.) In this sweetly nostalgic picture book about the passing of time, a young boy discovers a fluffy owlet in his back yard, and the two become fast friends over the course of a magical, sun-soaked summer. But when fall arrives, the boy must go to school, and the owl must migrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Lawyers Seek Meeting With Garland Over Special Counsel Inquiries
description: Two lawyers for the former president asserted that he was being treated unfairly in the investigations into his handling of classified documents and his efforts to remain in power.
content: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump sent a letter on Tuesday requesting a meeting with Attorney General Merrick B. Garland related to the special counsel investigations into Mr. Trump’s conduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Ryan Mac
title: Driver’s Licenses, Addresses, Photos: Inside How TikTok Shares User Data
description: Employees of the Chinese-owned video app have regularly posted user information on a messaging and collaboration tool called Lark, according to internal documents.
content: In August 2021, TikTok received a complaint from a British user, who flagged that a man had been “exposing himself and playing with himself” on a livestream she hosted on the video app. She also described past abuse she had experienced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: They Cuddled a Kiwi. New Zealand Said, ‘Stop That.’
description: Video of the national bird being handled by Miami zoo visitors caused an outcry in New Zealand. Even the prime minister weighed in.
content: Shy and retiring by nature, with a preference for solitude and the dark, few would describe Paora, 4, as a natural diplomat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and April Rubin
title: Tina Turner Is Remembered as a Resilient Trailblazer
description: Many said her music and her life story were inspirations as she overcame abuse during her marriage to Ike Turner and emerged as a star on her own.
content: Rock and soul singers, civil rights activists and political leaders mourned Tina Turner on Wednesday as a trailblazing artist whose music and life epitomized resilience, determination, heart and the power to not only survive but thrive over five decades in the music industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wendy Lu
title: How I Hold It Together: Comfort Meals and More
description: Wendy Lu, an editor at The New York Times, shares her strategies for taming anxiety.
content: Wendy Lu, an editor at The New York Times, shares her strategies for taming anxiety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: A Historic Skating Hub Returns
description: Decades ago, Brooklyn Banks was the epicenter of urban skateboarding. Now, it's back.
content: Decades ago, Brooklyn Banks was the epicenter of urban skateboarding. Now, it's back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Photographs and Text by Tamir Kalifa
title: After Uvalde, a Cemetery Anchors Families of Victims
description: A year after 19 children and two teachers were killed at a Texas elementary school, families of the victims have bonded through memories, grief and action.
content: A year after 19 children and two teachers were killed at a Texas elementary school, families of the victims have bonded through memories, grief and action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Blatt and Francesca Paris
title: How New Rules Turned Back the Clock on Baseball
description: Visualizing the effect of changes two months into the season.
content: Visualizing the effect of changes two months into the season.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Living In ... Pleasantville, N.Y
description: The Westchester community attracts an eclectic mix of residents who appreciate the artsy vibe, the charming homes and the proximity of the city.
content: The Westchester community attracts an eclectic mix of residents who appreciate the artsy vibe, the charming homes and the proximity of the city.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Orcas Slam Into Boat Off the Coast of Morocco
description: A small group of orcas slammed into the side of a sailing cruiser and chewed its rudder.
content: A small group of orcas slammed into the side of a sailing cruiser and chewed its rudder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mar-Vic Cagurangan
title: Strong Winds Hit Guam as Typhoon Mawar Approaches
description: President Biden declared an emergency for Guam on Tuesday night, and the governor warned that the island could take a direct hit from the typhoon.
content: President Biden declared an emergency for Guam on Tuesday night, and the governor warned that the island could take a direct hit from the typhoon.
source.name: The New York Times
